responses.response:
Key signature  
•  The excerpt shows a single sharp written on the top-line F of the treble staff.  
•  One sharp means the music is either in G major (F-sharp) or its relative minor, E minor.

Accidentals inside the excerpt  
•  There are no extra sharps, flats, or naturals anywhere in the melody other than the key-signature F-sharp.  
•  In E minor we would normally expect to see D-sharp (the raised 7th) somewhere, especially in an Allegro, because the leading tone is almost always used to point back to the tonic. Its complete absence is a first warning that we are probably not in E minor.

Melodic behaviour  
•  The line keeps circling around the notes G, B and D – the three tones that make up the G-major triad.  
•  The very first accented note is G (a strong beat), and the clearest arrival points at the middles of phrases are also on G or on the dominant D, which then resolves back to G.  
•  None of the phrase-ending notes sounds or looks like E; instead the melody feels settled when it lands on G, the tonic of G major.

Harmonic implications  
•  Cadential motion is dominantly D (dominant) → G (tonic).  
•  Again, nothing points to a typical minor dominant–tonic (B or B-major-like harmony) that would lead to an E-minor tonic.

Conclusion  
Putting these observations together—one sharp in the key signature, no raised 7th for E minor, repeated emphasis of the notes G–B–D, and phrase endings on G—the music is in G major.

responses.response:
Tonality: D major  

How I arrived at this conclusion  

1. Key signature  
   • Immediately after the treble clef there are two sharps.  
   • Two sharps mean the music is either in D major (its relative major) or B minor (its relative minor).

2. Accidentals inside the excerpt  
   • Every C that appears is already written on the third space of the staff and is not preceded by a sharp sign; that tells us C♯ is part of the key signature, not an added accidental.  
   • I do not see any A-sharp accidentals, which are very common in B-minor melodies (♯ ^7 used as the leading tone).  
   • There are no flats or naturals canceling the key-signature sharps.  
   Together this points toward a straightforward diatonic use of the scale with F♯ and C♯ only—typical of D major rather than B minor, which almost always adds A♯ in ascending figures or cadences.

3. Melodic outline and cadential notes  
   • The first strong pitch after the pickup is D (the tonic of D major).  
   • The music ends (right before the final barline) on D as well, and the approach to that final D is through A→G→F♯→E→D, a textbook dominant-to-tonic motion implying a V→I cadence in D major.  
   • Throughout the line the prominent structural tones are D, F♯, and A (the D-major triad).

4. Harmonic implications  
   • Scalar runs frequently outline D-major (D-E-F♯-G-A-B-C♯-D) and dominant–tonic gestures (A-F♯-D), reinforcing a major mode rather than the darker, leading-tone-inflected minor mode.

Because the key signature fits both D-major and B-minor, one must look at accidentals, melodic emphasis, and cadences. The consistent absence of A♯, the repeated arrival on D, and the dominant-to-tonic cadences all favor D major.

Therefore the passage is in D major.

   • The line often moves between E (tonic) and B (dominant), another common sign of E-minor orientation.

responses.response:
Written (alto-sax) key

1. Key-signature  
   • Two sharps are shown immediately after the treble clef.  
   • Two sharps can mean either D-major or B-minor.

2. Accidentals inside the excerpt  
   • All the sharps that appear in the passage are courtesy reminders (they keep F♯ and C♯ sharp).  
   • There are no A-sharps (the raised 7th that would be expected in B-minor).  
   • There are no G-sharps, double-sharps, or other accidentals that typically appear in a minor line to smooth the melodic form.

3. Melodic emphasis  
   • The opening figure outlines the notes D–F♯–A (the D-major triad).  
   • The longer slurred run in the middle also lands repeatedly on D and A, reinforcing tonic–dominant motion.  
   • Just before the double bar the line settles on a written D (with a dynamic taper), giving a clear sense of resolution.

4. Harmonic implication  
   • Because the melody stresses D and its dominant A, and because leading-tone alteration (A♯) never occurs, the harmonic pull feels major rather than minor.

Conclusion  
The written key of the excerpt is D major.  
(Since this is an E♭ alto saxophone part, the concert key would be F major, a major sixth lower.)
